k3 wyif sl1 k3 wyif sl1 k1 wyif sl1 k3 wyif sl1 k5 twice wyif sl1 k3 wyif sl1 k1 wyif sl1 k3 wyif sl1 k3 repeat row 1 to 32 once more and then row 1 to 30 ending row knit the last three row in the main color and then cast off tie off and weave in threads i know it sounds funny to have a different number of starting and ending row but this way you get two ridges on each end in the main color helpful notes you will quickly see that when you are working with the contrast color there is actually no need to slip the last stitch in the first row you can instead bring the yarn forward and turn the needles round with the last stitch still on the needle once you turn it around it is as though you have already slipped the stitch and moved your yarn ready into knitting position because the edging is made 2 row by knitting the first and last stitches and 2 row by slipping the first and last stitches you want to make sure that your last knit row is not super tight as it will need to extend over two row before you knit it again charted patterns notes to help with the charts please read before you start… if you are a visual knitter then you will find the charts much easier to work from with the exception of the first two and last three row which are just knitted then a mc row indicated by a blue square to the right of the chart will represent two row of knitting the first in which all mc squares are knitted and cc squares are slipped and the return row where mc squares are again knitted but cc squares are skipped by bringing the yarn forward first cc row no colored square to the right of chart work the same way except you are knitting cc squares and skipping mc squares i have included a chart for a coaster size mat this is made in the same way except that the edging looks a little different and you will not be stretching the same color all the way up the sides… in all charts mc squares are red cc squares are not colored blues squares are not part of the pattern but indicate mc blue or cc nothing row each square except for the first and last two red row represents two row of knitting and any colored squares below a chart are there to indicate the stitch count each block of color represents 10 stitches charts should be read from right
